sim¶

sim.Sim¶

The simulation class treats field indicies as follows

Both the electric and magnetic fields are initialized to the same length, meaning that they have a slight offset in starting and ending locations in the simulation. The field at each time is stored in a Numpy array. The Numpy arrays are stored in a list, which allows each field at previous times to be accessed.

  • Discuss the choice of \(\frac{\Delta t}{\Delta z}\approx c\)
  • Discuss how to create a current object
class sim.Sim(vacuum_permittivity, infinity_permittivity, vacuum_permeability, delta_t, delta_z, num_n, num_i, current_field, susceptibility, initial_susceptibility)[source]¶

Represents a single simulation. Field is initialized to all zeros.

Parameters:
  • vacuum_permittivity – \(\epsilon_0\)
  • infinity_permittivity – \(\epsilon_\infty\)
  • vacuum_permeability – \(\mu_0\)
  • delta_t – \(\Delta t\)
  • delta_z – \(\Delta z\)
  • num_n – The number of time indexes
  • num_i – The number of spatial indexes
  • current – A field object that represents the current
  • susceptibility – A susceptibility object
  • initial_susceptibility – The initial susceptability. Eventually will be included in the susceptibility object.

psi()[source]¶

Calculates psi according to \(\psi^n=\sum^{n-1}_{m=0}E^{i,n-m}\Delta\chi_e^m\) at the current time \(n\) and position \(i\). Currently not implemented, and will simply return zero.

Returns:Zero
simulate()[source]¶

Executes the simulation

sim.Field¶

The field class can store both current field values as well as past field values as as Numpy array. The E-field array has the following structure

The H-field array has a corresponding structure. The user never directly interacts with the entire Numpy array. Rather they set a “current time \(n\)” which selects a row of the array. Any further operations are performed on that row. The sim.Field.export() function simply returns the Numpy field.

class sim.Field(num_n, num_i)[source]¶

Represents any field (i.e. electric, magnetic, current, susceptibility) using a 2D Numpy array. The zeroth axis represents increments in time and the first axis represents increments in space.

Parameters:
  • num_n – The number of temporal indexes in the field
  • num_i – The number of spatial indexes in the field
export()[source]¶

Returns the Numpy array that contains the temporal (axis=0) and spatial values (axis=1) of the field.

Returns:A Numpy array
get_field(n=-1)[source]¶

Gets the field at time \(n\), and the current time if \(n\) is unspecified.

Parameters:n – \(n\)
Returns:The field at time n
get_index(i)[source]¶

Gets the value of the field at the current time index \(n\) and at the \(i\) th spatial index. If the requested index is out of the field bounds, the returned value is zero.

Parameters:i – The spatial index of the field to access
Returns:The value of the field a the current time index \(n\) and spatial index \(i\)
get_time_index()[source]¶

Gets the current time index \(n\)

Returns:The current time index \(n\)
set_field(nfield, n=-1)[source]¶

Sets the field at time \(n\), and the current time if \(n\) is unspecified. Raises a ValueError if the new field is not of the correct spatial length.

Parameters:nfield – The new field to append of length num_i
set_index(i, value)[source]¶

Sets the value of the field at the current time index \(n\) and at the \(i\) th spatial index.

Parameters:
  • i – The spatial index of the field to set
  • value – The value to set at time index \(n\) and spatial index \(i\)
set_time_index(n)[source]¶

Sets the current time index to \(n\)

Parameters:n – \(n\)
